facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 307 of 1963 filed by the defendant (appellant).

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 307 of 1963. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated September 27, 1962 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 158 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree- dated September 27, 1962, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 158 of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 24, 1963 by MUDHOLKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: October 24, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed the defendant's appeal challenging ejectment order by courts below.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Additional Solicitor-General of India, O.C. Mathur, Revindra Narain and J.B. Dadachanji for the appellant. C. Setalvad, Rameshwar Nath and S.N. Andley, for the respondents. October 24, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dismissing the defendants appeal in which he had challenged the decision of the courts below ordering his ejectment from certain premises which are in his occupation as the tenant of the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Defendant was a tenant of the plaintiffs; rent Rs. 110 per month.

anchor.surface_text: the tenant of the plaintiffs. It is common ground that the defendant was a tenant of the plaintiffs and the rent of the premises in his occupation was Rs. 110 p.m.

facts.text: Defendant in arrears of rent from April 1, 1958 to March 31, 1959 amounting to Rs. 1,020.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the defendant was in arrears of rent from April 1, 1958 to March 31, 1959 to the extent of Rs. 1,020.

facts.text: Plaintiffs served notice on defendant on April 11, 1959 demanding Rs. 1,020 within one month or face ejectment suit.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1959 the plaintiffs served a notice on the defendant bringing to his notice the fact of his being in arrears of rent for 12 months and requiring him to remit to them Rs. 1,020 within one month from the date of service of notice and stating that on his failure to do so, a suit for ejectment would be filed against him.

facts.text: Notice also required defendant to vacate by April 30, 1959 on grounds of bona fide business need and unauthorized subletting.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to this the notice called upon the defendant to vacate the premises by April 30, 1959 upon two grounds 1 that the premises were required by the plaintiffs genuinely for business and 2 that the defendant had sublet a portion of the premises to two persons without the permission of the plaintiffs and without having any right to sublet the premises.

facts.text: Defendant received notice on April 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This notice was received by the defendant on April 16, 1959.

facts.text: Defendant sent reply on June 25, 1959 with cheque for Rs. 1,320 covering arrears up to June 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On June 25, 1959 the defendant sent a reply to the notice enclosing with it a cheque for Rs. 1,320. It may be mentioned that this amount consisted of the rental arrears as well as the rent due right up to June 30, 1959.

facts.text: Plaintiffs cashed the cheque on July 4, 1959 under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs accepted the cheque and cashed it on July 4, 1959 and gave a fresh notice on July 9, 1959 requiring the defendant to vacate the premises by the end of the month of July. In their notice the plaintiffs also stated that they had cashed the cheque under protest.

facts.text: Plaintiffs issued fresh notice on July 9, 1959 to vacate by end of July.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs accepted the cheque and cashed it on July 4, 1959 and gave a fresh notice on July 9, 1959 requiring the defendant to vacate the premises by the end of the month of July.

facts.text: Suit for eviction instituted on August 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant did not vacate the premises and, therefore, the present suit for eviction was instituted on August 14, 1959.

facts.text: Courts below negatived claims of bona fide need and illegal subletting.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claim for eviction on the grounds that the premises were required by them bona fide for the purpose of their business and that the defendant had illegally let them out was negatived by the courts below and, therefore, must be left out of question.

facts.text: Premises situated in Jabalpur where Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955 is in force.

anchor.surface_text: The premises are, however, situated in Jabalpur in which the Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act,1955 No. 23 of 1955 herein referred as the Accommodation Act is in force.

facts.text: Defendant failed to pay arrears within one month of notice service.

anchor.surface_text: From the undisputed facts it is clear that the defendant was in fact in arrears of rent and had failed to pay it within the time prescribed by cl. a of s. 4.

facts.text: Tenancy is month to month.

anchor.surface_text: The tenancy being from month to month it was open to the plaintiffs to terminate it by giving 15 days notice expiring at the end of the month of the tenancy as provided for in s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.

facts.text: April 11, 1959 notice received on April 16, providing only 14 clear days notice.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the day on which it expires is taken into account it will be clear that the defendant had only 14 clear days notice. Therefore, if the view taken in the aforesaid case is correct the period of notice falls short of that provided in s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act by one day.

facts.text: Supreme Court held April 11 notice ineffective under s.106 TPA due to short notice period.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, approve of the view taken in Subadini's case and hold that the notice dated April 11, 1959 was ineffective as it does not fulfil the requirements of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Suit based on July 9, 1959 notice which complied with s.106 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the plaintiffs, however, points out that a notice complying with the requirements of s. 106 was actually given by the plaintiffs to the defendant on July 9, 1959 and no fault could be found with it since it in fact gave more than 15 days clear notice to the defendant to vacate the premises.

facts.text: No arrears of rent on date of suit August 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that there were actually no arrears on the date of suit and that unless a tenant is in arrears on the date of suit he is not liable to be evicted because of the provisions of s. 4 a of the Accommodation Act.

facts.text: Court held ground under s.4(a) need not subsist on date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt, therefore, that the ground set out in cl. a of s. 4 need not be shown by the landlord to exist at the date of institution of the suit.

facts.text: Acceptance of rent cheque did not waive the default under s.4(a).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the argument of the learned Additional Solicitor-General that by cashing the cheque for Rs. 1,320 the plaintiffs waived all rights which accrued to them under the notice dated April 11, 1959.
Section 4 of the Act provides that no suit shall be filed. in any civil court against a tenant for his eviction from any accommodation except on one or more of the grounds set out in that section.

concepts.interpretation: No suit for eviction except on specified grounds; cl.(a) allows eviction if tenant fails to pay arrears of rent within one month of service of written notice of demand; this ground need not subsist on the date of suit.

issues.text: whether the plaintiffs are entitled to eject the defendant upon the ground that the latter was in arrears of rent for one year and had failed to pay the arrears within one month of the service of the notice dated April 11, 1959 upon him

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General contends-and rightly-that the provisions of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act are in addition to those of the Transfer of Property Act and that before a tenant can be evicted by a landlord he must comply both with the provisions of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and those of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act.

anchor.surface_text: the legislature intended to give protection only to a tenant who was diligent and regular enough in the matter of payment of rent. That is all.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act are in addition to those of the Transfer of Property Act and both s.106 TPA and s.4 must be complied with for eviction.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General contends-and rightly-that the provisions of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act are in addition to those of the Transfer of Property Act and that before a tenant can be evicted by a landlord he must comply both with the provisions of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and those of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accommodation Act does not abrogate Ch. V TPA; s.106 required to terminate tenancy, s.4 provides additional grounds bar.

holdings.text: The notice dated April 11, 1959 was a composite notice under s.4(a) Accommodation Act and s.106 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has, however, treated this as a composite notice under s. 4 a of the Accommodation Act and s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and in our opinion rightly. It has to be observed that the plaintiffs, after requiring

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice required payment of arrears and threatened ejectment, indicating intention to terminate under both Acts.

holdings.text: Notice under s.106 TPA must provide 15 clear days, excluding day of service; approves Subadini case.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the Calcutta High Court in Subadini v. Durga Charan Lal 1 that the notice contemplated by s. 106 must be notice of 15 clear days. In calculating the 15 days notice the day on which the notice is served is excluded

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Calcutta HC precedent; rejects liberal construction depriving tenant of minimum period benefit.

holdings.text: The April 11, 1959 notice ineffective under s.106 TPA as only 14 clear days.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, approve of the view taken in Subadini's case and hold that the notice dated April 11, 1959 was ineffective as it does not fulfil the requirements of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant had only 14 clear days; liberal construction not permissible to shorten minimum notice.

holdings.text: July 9, 1959 notice complies with s.106 TPA; suit competently based on it.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the plaintiffs, however, points out that a notice complying with the requirements of s. 106 was actually given by the plaintiffs to the defendant on July 9, 1959 and no fault could be found with it since it in fact gave more than 15 days clear notice to the defendant to vacate the premises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gave more than 15 clear days; contention correct.

holdings.text: Ground under cl.(a) s.4 Accommodation Act need not subsist on date of suit; only failure within one month of notice required.

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt, therefore, that the ground set out in cl. a of s. 4 need not be shown by the landlord to exist at the date of institution of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal meaning of clause; distinguishes other clauses with different language; no rewriting of statute.

holdings.text: Acceptance of rent cheque does not waive default under s.4(a); tenancy continues, rent payable.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the argument of the learned Additional Solicitor-General that by cashing the cheque for Rs. 1,320 the plaintiffs waived all rights which accrued to them under the notice dated April 11, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid termination under s.106 so landlord-tenant relation continues; acceptance does not imply waiver of statutory eviction right.

holdings.text: Illustration (a) to s.113 TPA not applicable; no waiver of notice to quit by rent acceptance here.

anchor.surface_text: this is not a case to which illustration a to s. 113 of the Transfer of Property Act which says that acceptance of rent falling due after the expiry of a notice to quit amounts to waiver of the notice applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No expiry of valid notice to quit; suit based on later notice.

holdings.text: s.4(a) does not create forfeiture; s.114 TPA relief against non-payment available; merely removes eviction bar.

anchor.surface_text: the benefit of s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act which provides for relief against forfeiture for non-payment of rent. What is forfeiture is set out in s. 111 g of the Transfer of Property Act, which runs thus By forfeiture that is to say,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(a) adds condition to s.106 exercise but does not insert re-entry clause or alter tenancy nature.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs entitled to evict defendant under s.4(a) for failure to pay arrears within one month of April 11 notice.

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether the plaintiffs are entitled to eject the defendant upon the ground that the latter was in arrears of rent for one year and had failed to pay the arrears within one month of the service of the notice dated April 11, 1959 upon him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Default established; no waiver; valid s.106 notice given subsequently; ground need not subsist at suit.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the Calcutta High Court in Subadini v. Durga Charan Lal 1  that the numberice companytemplated by s. 106 must be numberice of 15 clear days. In calculating the 15 days numberice the day on which the numberice is served is excluded and even if the day on which it expires is taken into account it will be clear that the defendant had only 14 clear days numberice. Therefore, if the view taken in the aforesaid case is companyrect the period of numberice falls short of that provided in s. 1.06 of the Transfer of Property Act by one day.

precedents.cited_proposition: notice under s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act requires 15 clear days excluding the day of service
precedents.cited_holding: the notice contemplated by s. 106 must be notice of 15 clear days. In calculating the 15 days notice the day on which the notice is served is excluded

anchor.surface_text: But Mr. Setalvad who appears for the plaintiffs, companytends that a numberice to quit should be liberally companystrued. In this companynection he referred us to a decision in Harihar Banerji v. Ramsashi Roy In that case the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council has observed at p. 225 that numberices to quite, though number strictly accurate or companysistent in the statements embodied in them, may still be good and effective in law that the test of their sufficiency is number what they would mean to a stranger ignorant of all the facts and, circumstances touching the holding to which they purport to refer, but what they would mean to tenants presumably companyversant with all those facts and circumstances and, further, that they are to be companystrued, number with a desire to find faults in them which would render them defective, but to be companystrued at res magis valeat quam pereat.

precedents.cited_proposition: notices to quit should be liberally construed; what they would mean to tenants conversant with facts; res magis valeat quam pereat
precedents.cited_holding: notices to quit, though not strictly accurate or consistent in the statements embodied in them, may still be good and effective in law that the test of their sufficiency is not what they would mean to a stranger ignorant of all the facts and circumstances touching the holding to which they purport to refer, but what they would mean to tenants presumably conversant with all those facts and circumstances and, further, that they are to be construed, not with a desire to find faults in them which would render them defective, but to be construed ut res magis valeat quam pereat

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor-General contends-and rightly-that the provisions of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act are in addition to those of the Transfer of Property Act and that before a tenant can be evicted by a landlord he must comply both with the provisions of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and those of s. 4 of the Accommodation Act.
We think the contention to be correct. This brings us to the second and the fourth points raised by the learned Additional Solicitor-General which we will deal with together.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad for the plaintiffs, however, points out that a notice complying with the requirements of s. 106 was actually given by the plaintiffs to the defendant on July 9, 1959 and no fault could be found with it since it in fact gave more than 15 days clear notice to the defendant to vacate the premises.
We think the contention to be correct. This brings us to the second and the fourth points raised by the learned Additional Solicitor-General which we will deal with together.
